207<html>

<head>
<title>The One Where Ross Finds Out</title>
</head>

<body bgcolor="white" text="black" link="green" vlink="black" alink="yellow">

<h1 align="center">The One Where Ross Finds Out</h1>

<hr align="center">
<font size="3"><i>

<p>Originally written by Michael Borkow<br>
Transcribed by <a href="josh.html">Josh Hodge</i></font></a><br>
<i>Minor additions and adjustments by Dan Silverstein.</i><br>
</p>

<hr>
<font size="3">

<p align="left">[Scene: Monica and Rachel's apartment. Everyone is sitting at the couches,
Chandler enters.]<br>
<br>
CHAN: OK, what is it about me? Do I not look fun enough? Is there something. . .
repellant. . . about me?<br>
<br>
RACH: So, how was the party?<br>
<br>
CHAN: Well it couldn't have been worse. A woman literally passed <b>through</b> me. OK, so
what is it, am I hideously unattractive?<br>
<br>
PHOE: No, you are not, you are very attractive. You know what, I go through the exact same
thing. Every time I put on a little weight, I start questioning everyting.<br>
<br>
CHAN: Woah, woah, I've put on a little weight?<br>
<br>
PHOE: No, not wieght... y'know, more like insulation.<br>
<br>
MNCA: Chandler, I'm unemployed and in dire need of a project. Ya wanna work out? I can
remake you.<br>
<br>
CHAN: Oh, you know, I would, but that might get in the way of my lying around time.<br>
<br>
MNCA: Please.<br>
<br>
ALL: C'mon. Let her. Yeah.<br>
<br>
CHAN: Alright, OK, alright. But if we put on spandex and my boobs are bigger than yours,
I'm goin' home.<br>
<br>
PHOE: Your boobs are fine. Look, I never should have said anything. Come here. Come here.
[hugs Chandler but holds her hands apart behind his back] Oh, can't make.... hands...
meet....<br>
<br>
<font size="4"><b>OPENING TITLES</b></font> <br>
<br>
[Scene: Hallway between the apartments. Chandler comes out wearing spandex, jogging in
place. Monica is there.]<br>
<br>
CHAN: OK, let's do it. [Monica looks at him funny] What?<br>
<br>
MNCA: Nothing, just never seen you in little stretchy pants before.<br>
<br>
CHAN: And we're changing. [jogs back in his apartment]<br>
<br>
[Cut to the city street. Monica and Chandler are jogging. Chandler is lagging behind so he
hops in a cab and takes off, leaving Monica behind]<br>
<br>
[Scene: Back in Chandler and Joey's apartment. Chandler is doing situps.]<br>
<br>
MNCA: C'mon give me five more. Five more.<br>
<br>
CHAN: [weakly] No.<br>
<br>
MNCA: Five more and I'll flash you.<br>
<br>
CHAN: One. . . two. . . two and a half. OK, just show me one of them.<br>
<br>
[Scene: Central Perk. Chandler and Joey are sitting on the couch. Rachel is working.]<br>
<br>
CHAN: [slowly lifts coffee cup to his mouth] Ow, ow, ow, ow, ow, ow, ow. [slowly sets the
cup back down] Ow, ow, ow, ow, ow. [Joey intercepts the cup and puts it down for him].
She's insane, the woman is insane. It's before work, it's after work, it's during work.
She's got me doing butt clenches at my desk. And now, they won't bring me my mail anymore.<br>
<br>
[Phoebe enters.]<br>
<br>
RACH: Hey Phoebs, how'd it go with Scott last night?<br>
<br>
PHOE: Oh, um, it was nice. Took him to a romantic restraunt, ordered champagne, nice.<br>
<br>
JOEY: The guy still won't put out, huh?<br>
<br>
PHOE: Nope. Zilch, nothin', uh-uh.<br>
<br>
ALL: Sorry Phoebs.<br>
<br>
PHOE: Look, I, y'know, I don't mind taking it slow, I like him a lot, y'know he's really
interesting and he's really sweet and why won't he give it up?<br>
<br>
JOEY: Maybe he, uhh... drives his car on the other side of the road, if ya know what I
mean.<br>
<br>
PHOE: No, whad'ya mean? He's not British.<br>
<br>
JOEY: Maybe he's. . . gay.<br>
<br>
PHOE: Oohh, um, no, I don't think that's the problem. 'Cause we went, um, dancing the
other night and the way he held me so close, and the way he was looking into my eyes I
just like... definitely felt something.<br>
<br>
RACH: Yeah, but how much can you tell from a look?<br>
<br>
PHOE: No, I felt it on my hip. You could tell.<br>
<br>
[Monica enters.]<br>
<br>
MNCA: [to Chandler] Yo, Bing. Racquetball in 15 minutes.<br>
<br>
CHAN: Joey, be a pal. Lift up my hand and smack her with it.<br>
<br>
PHOE: [seeing Ross kissing Julie outside the window] Ooh, oh, Rachel, don't look.<br>
<br>
RACH: What? [looks, feigns indifference] C'mon you guys, I don't care, I have a date
tonight.<br>
<br>
JOEY: Woah, woah, woah, you have a date?<br>
<br>
RACH: Yeah, Monica's settin' me up.<br>
<br>
JOEY: But uh, uh, what about uh, Ross and uh. . .?<br>
<br>
RACH: Oh what, my whole insane jealousy thing? Well, y'know, as much fun as that was, I've
decided to opt for sanity.<br>
<br>
CHAN: So you really OK about all this?<br>
<br>
RACH: Oh yeah, c'mon, I'm movin' on. He can press her up against that window as much as he
wants. For all I care, he can throw her through the damn thing.<br>
<br>
[Ross and Julie enter.]<br>
<br>
ROSS: Hi guys.<br>
<br>
ALL: Hey.<br>
<br>
ROSS: Oh, Monica, I figured I'd come by tomorrow morning and pick up Fluffy's old cat toy,
OK?<br>
<br>
MNCA: Only if you say his full name.<br>
<br>
ROSS: [reluctantly] Can I come over tomorrow and pick up Fluffy Meowington's cat toy.<br>
<br>
MNCA: Alright.<br>
<br>
JOEY: [to Ross] You're getting a cat?<br>
<br>
ROSS: Uh, actually, we're getting a cat.<br>
<br>
RACH: Together?<br>
<br>
ROSS: Uh huh.<br>
<br>
RACH: Both of you?<br>
<br>
ROSS: Yep.<br>
<br>
RACH: Together.<br>
<br>
JULIE: Yeah, we figure it'll live with Ross half the time, and with me half the time.<br>
<br>
RACH: Ohh, well, isn't that just lovely. That's something the two of you will be able to
enjoy for a really, really, really, really, really long time.<br>
<br>
ROSS: Hopefully.<br>
<br>
RACH: Well. [looks at watch] Woah, look at that! I gotta go, I gotta date. With a man. Um,
OK, you guys have a really, uh, have a really good night and you two have a, uh, have a,
uh, really good cat. [she leaves carrying her tray then comes back in] OK, we're not
supposed to take these when we leave.<br>
<br>
[Scene: A nice restraunt. Rachel is on her date with Michael (MICH).]<br>
<br>
MICH: I don't know if Monica told you but this is the first date I've gone on since my
divorce so, if I seem a little nervous, I am.<br>
<br>
RACH: [distracted] How long do cats live?<br>
<br>
MICH: [confused] I'm sorry?<br>
<br>
RACH: Cats, how long do they live figuring you don't... y'know, throw 'em under a bus or
something?<br>
<br>
MICH: Um, maybe 15, 16 years.<br>
<br>
RACH: That's just great. [she picks up her champagne and starts drinking]<br>
<br>
MICH: Um, cheers.<br>
<br>
RACH: Oh, right, clink. [downs her glass]<br>
<br>
MICH: Monica told you I was cuter that this, didn't she?<br>
<br>
RACH: Oh, no, Michael, it's not you. I'm sorry, it's just, it's this thing. It's probably
not as bad as it sounds but this friend of mine is, is getting a cat with his girlfriend.<br>
<br>
MICH: Oh, that does sound. . .Ahh.<br>
<br>
RACH: I mean he just started going out with her.<br>
<br>
MICH: Is this guy, uhh, an old boyfriend?<br>
<br>
RACH: Ah, hah-hah-hah-ho, yeah, he wishes. Oh, I'm sorry, look at me. OK, Michael, let's
talk about you. <br>
<br>
MICH: Alright.<br>
<br>
RACH: OK, OK. So, you ever get a pet with a girlfriend?<br>
<br>
[Scene: Central Perk. Phoebe and Joey are sitting on the couch.]<br>
<br>
PHOE: So, I figured it out.<br>
<br>
JOEY: What?<br>
<br>
PHOE: Why Scott doesn't want to sleep with me. It's 'cause I'm not sexy enough.<br>
<br>
JOEY: Phoebe, that's crazy. When I first met you, you know what I said to Chandler? I
said, &quot;Excellent butt, great rack.&quot;<br>
<br>
PHOE: Really? That's so sweet. I mean, I'm officially offended but, sweet.<br>
<br>
JOEY: Phoebs look, if you want to know what the deal is, you're just gonna have to ask
him.<br>
<br>
PHOE: You're right, you're right. Ah, you are so yumm. [they hug]<br>
<br>
[Outside the window, Monica and Chandler jog up. Monica playfully pushes him. They start
puching and slapping harder and harder until Monica pushes him down. Chandler stands up,
with a serious expression, and chases her away.]<br>
<br>
[Scene: Back in the restraunt. Rachel pours the last of the champange bottle in her
glass.]<br>
<br>
RACH: [obviously drunk] I mean, it's a cat, y'know, it's a <b>cat</b>. Why can't they get
one of those bugs, y'know, one of those fruitflies, those things that live for like a day
or something? [belligerently] What're they called, what're they called, what're they
called?<br>
<br>
MICH: Fruitflies?<br>
<br>
RACH: Yes! Thank you.<br>
<br>
[The waiter comes to the table.]<br>
<br>
WAITER: So, would you like any dessert?<br>
<br>
MICH: No! No dessert, just a check, please.<br>
<br>
RACH: Oh, you're not having fun, are you?<br>
<br>
MICH: No, no, I am, but only because for the last hour and a half I've been playing the
movie <i>Diner</i> in my head.<br>
<br>
RACH: Oh, look at me, look at me. Oh, I'm on a date with a really great guy, all I can
think about is Ross and his cat and his... Julie. I just want to get over him. gosh, why
can't I do that?<br>
<br>
MICH: Oy. Look, I've been through a divorce, trust me you're gonna be fine. You just can't
see it now because you haven't had any closure.<br>
<br>
RACH: Yeah! Closure. That's what it is, that's what I need. God, you're brilliant! Why
didn't I think of that? How do I get that?<br>
<br>
MICH: Well, you know, there's no one way really, it's just, you know, whatever it takes so
that you can finally say to him, &quot;I'm over you.&quot;<br>
<br>
RACH: Closure, that's what it is. Closure. [she looks around the restaurant, spotting a
guy with a cellular phone] Hello, excuse me. Excuse me, hel. . . woo [she almost falls out
of her chair]<br>
<br>
GUY: Hang on.<br>
<br>
RACH: Hello, excuse me.<br>
<br>
GUY: What.<br>
<br>
RACH: Hi, I'm sorry, I need to borrow your phone for just one minute.<br>
<br>
GUY: I'm talkin'!<br>
<br>
RACH: I can see that. I... just one phone call, I'll be very quick, I'll even pay for it
myself. [man is still reluctant] OK, you're bein' a little weird about your phone.<br>
<br>
GUY: Alright, fine. [on the phone] I'll call you back. [hands the phone to her]<br>
<br>
RACH: Thank you. OK. [dials] [to Michael] Machine. Just waiting for the beep.<br>
<br>
MICH: Good.<br>
<br>
RACHEL: [on phone] Ross, hi, it's Rachel. I'm just calling to say that um, everything's
fine and I'm really happy for you and your cat who, by the way, I think you should name
Michael. And, you know, ya see there I'm thinking of names so obviously, I am over you. I
am over you and that, my friend, is what they call closure. [hangs up and tosses phone in
the ice bucket]<br>
<br>
</p>

<h3 align="center"><strong>COMMERCIAL BREAK</strong></h3>

<p><br>
[Scene: Chandler and Joey's apartment. Chandler is answering the door in his robe.]<br>
<br>
CHAN: No, no, no, no, no, no [opens door to Monica] No. Monica, it's Sunday morning. I'm
not running on a Sunday.<br>
<br>
MNCA: Why not?<br>
<br>
CHAN: Because it's Sunday. It's God's day.<br>
<br>
MNCA: OK, if you say stop, then we stop.<br>
<br>
CHAN: OK, stop.<br>
<br>
MNCA: No, c'mon, we can't stop, c'mon, we've got three more pounds to go. I am the energy
train and you are on board. Woo-woo, woo-woo, woo-woo [Chandler walks out of the
apartment, leaving Monica] Woo.<br>
<br>
[Scene: Rachel and Monica's apartment. Rachel is taking asprin. Ross enters.]<br>
<br>
ROSS: Hey Rach.<br>
<br>
RACH: Ahhhh.<br>
<br>
ROSS: Oh. And how was the date? <br>
<br>
RACH: Umm, I think there was a restaurant... I know there was wine. . .<br>
<br>
[Rachel looks at Ross as though she remembers something, but can't place what it is.]</p>

<p>ROSS: Wow, well uh, uh, actually, Julie's downstairs getting a cab, I just need the cat
toy, did Monica say. . . What? Why, why are you looking at me like that?<br>
<br>
RACH: I don't know, I, I feel like I had a dream about you last night but I, I don't
remember.<br>
<br>
ROSS: OK. Oh, oh, oh. [runs over and picks up the cat toy]<br>
<br>
RACH: Did we speak on the phone last night? Did you call me?<br>
<br>
ROSS: No, I stayed at Julie's last night.<br>
<br>
RACH: Huh.<br>
<br>
ROSS: Oh, actually I haven't even been home yet. Do you mind if I check my messages?<br>
<br>
RACH: Oh yeah, go ahead. [Rachel walks in her room. Ross picks up the phone and dials his
machine to check his messages.]<br>
<br>
ROSS: Rach, I got a message from you. [pauses] Who's Michael?<br>
<br>
[Rachel comes out of her room, suddenly she remembers leaving the message.]</p>

<p>RACH: Oh my God. Oh my God Ross, no, hang up the phone, give me the phone Ross, give me
the phone, give me the phone, give me the. . . [jumps the couch and lands on Ross's back,
finally getting the phone from him. Ross has a confused expression on his face.]<br>
<br>
ROSS: You're over me?<br>
<br>
RACH: Ohhhhhhhh God. [climbs off his back]<br>
<br>
ROSS: Wha... you're uh, you're, you're over me?<br>
<br>
RACH: Ohh, ohh.<br>
<br>
ROSS: When, when were you... under me? Rach. Rachel do you, I mean, were you, uh. . .
What?<br>
<br>
RACH: Ohh, OK, OK, OK, well, basically, lately, I've uh, I've uh, sort of had feelings for
you.<br>
<br>
ROSS: You've had feelings for me?<br>
<br>
RACH: Yeah, what, so? You had feelings for me first.<br>
<br>
ROSS: Woah. Huh. You know about my, I mean, you know I had... you know?<br>
<br>
RACH: Chandler told me.<br>
<br>
ROSS: Chandler. When did he... when did he... when did he?<br>
<br>
RACH: When you were in China.<br>
<br>
ROSS: China.<br>
<br>
RACH: Meeting Julie.<br>
<br>
ROSS: Julie. Julie. That. Oh God. Julie, right. OK, I need to lie down. No, ya know, I'm
gonna stand. I'm gonna stand, I'm gonna walk, I'm walkin' and I am standing. OK so you uh,
and now wha... and now, now, now you're over me?<br>
<br>
RACH: Are you over me?<br>
<br>
[A moment of silence.] <br>
<br>
ROSS: [doorbell buzzes] That's, that's Julie. Ju... Julie, Julie. [talks on intercom] Hi
Julie.<br>
<br>
JULIE: [over intercom] Hi honey, I've got a cab waiting.<br>
<br>
ROSS: [perky] I'll be right down.<br>
<br>
RACH: Wait, so, you're going?<br>
<br>
ROSS: Well, OK, I uh, I have to. I can't deal with this right now. I mean, I've uh,
y'know, I've got a cab, I've got a girlfriend, I'm... I'm gonna go get a cat.<br>
<br>
RACH: OK, OK.<br>
<br>
ROSS: Cat. [leaves]<br>
<br>
[Scene: Chandler and Joey's apartment. Joey is watching a rabbi play an electric guitar on
TV. Phoebe enters.]<br>
<br>
PHOE: Hey Joey.<br>
<br>
JOEY: Hey Phoebs.<br>
<br>
PHOE: How come you're watching a rabbi play electric guitar?<br>
<br>
JOEY: I can't find the remote. [Phoebe turns off the TV] Thank you.<br>
<br>
PHOE: So, Scott asked me to come over for lunch today and I did.<br>
<br>
JOEY: And?<br>
<br>
PHOE: And we did.<br>
<br>
JOEY: All right Phoebs, way to go.<br>
<br>
PHOE: Yay me.<br>
<br>
JOEY: So, so how did it happen?<br>
<br>
PHOE: Well, I finally took your advice and asked him what was going on.<br>
<br>
JOEY: And what did he say?<br>
<br>
PHOE: He said that, um, he understands how sex can be like, a very emotional thing for a
woman and he was just afraid that I was gonna get all, y'know, like, 'ohh, is he gonna
call me the next day' and, y'know, 'where is this going' and, ya know, blah-la-la-la-la.
So he said he wanted to hold off until he was prepared to be really serious.<br>
<br>
JOEY: Wow.<br>
<br>
PHOE: Yeah, so I said, &quot;OK, relax please,&quot; y'know, I mean, sex can be just about
two people right there in the moment, y'know, it's, if he wants to see me again he can
call and if not, that's fine too. So after a looooot of talking. . . I convinced him.<br>
<br>
JOEY: Let me get this straight. He got you to beg to sleep with him, he got you to say he
never has to call you again, and he got you thinking this was a great idea.<br>
<br>
PHOE: Um-hum.<br>
<br>
JOEY: This man is my God.<br>
<br>
[Scene: Central Perk. Rachel is closing up and Ross comes in. Get your Kleenex.]<br>
<br>
RACH: Hi.<br>
<br>
ROSS: I didn't get a cat.<br>
<br>
RACH: Oh, that's um, interesting.<br>
<br>
ROSS: No, no it's not interesting. OK, it's very, very not interesting. In fact it's
actually 100 percent completely opposite of interesting.<br>
<br>
RACH: Alright, I got it Ross.<br>
<br>
ROSS: You had no right to tell me you ever had feelings for me.<br>
<br>
RACH: [hurt] What?<br>
<br>
ROSS: I was doing great with Julie before I found out about you.<br>
<br>
RACH: Hey, I was doin' great before I found out about you. You think it's easy for me to
see you with Julie?<br>
<br>
ROSS: Then you should have said something before I met her.<br>
<br>
RACH: I didn't know then. And how come you never said anything to me.<br>
<br>
ROSS: There was never a good time.<br>
<br>
RACH: Right, you, you only had a year. We only hung out every night.<br>
<br>
ROSS: Not, not, not <b>every night</b>. You know, and... and it's not like I didn't try,
Rachel, but things got in the way, y'know? Like, like Italian guys or ex-fiances or, or,
or Italian guys.<br>
<br>
RACH: Hey, there was one Italian guy, OK, and do you even have a point?<br>
<br>
ROSS: The point is I... I don't need this right now, OK. It, it's too late, I'm with
somebody else, I'm happy. This ship has sailed.<br>
<br>
RACH: Yeah, what're you saying, you just sort of put away feelings or whatever the hell it
was you felt for me?<br>
<br>
ROSS: Hey, I've been doin' it since the ninth grade, I've gotten pretty damn good at it.<br>
<br>
RACH: Alright, fine, you go ahead and you do that, alright Ross.<br>
<br>
ROSS: Fine.<br>
<br>
RACH: 'Cause I don't need your stupid ship.<br>
<br>
ROSS: Good.<br>
<br>
RACH: Good. [Ross leaves] </p>

<p>[Rachel gets up and opens the door, yelling after him.]</p>

<p align="left">RACH: And ya know what, now I've got closure.<br>
<br>
[Rachel slams the door and locks it. She sits down, visibly upset. She puts her head in
her hands and begins to cry. Ross comes back and is standing outside the window. When
Rachel regroups and gets back up to finish closing, she sees him. She smiles. She goes to
open the door and can't get the lock undone.]<br>
<br>
ROSS: Try the bottom one.<br>
<br>
[She opens the door and they kiss.]<br>
<br>
[Scene: Chandler and Joey's apartment. Chandler answers the door to find Monica.]<br>
<br>
<font size="4"><b>CLOSING CREDITS</b></font> <br>
<br>
CHAN: Monica, it's 6:30 in the morning. We're not working out, it's over.<br>
<br>
MNCA: No way, with one pound to go, c'mon. We're workin', we're movin', we're in the zone
we're groovin'.<br>
<br>
CHAN: OK, I don't, I don't mind the last pound. OK, in fact I kind of like the last pound.
OK, so don't make me do anything that I'll regret.<br>
<br>
MNCA: Ooh, what'cha gonna do, fat boy, huh? What?<br>
<br>
CHAN: Nothing, except tell you, uh, I think it's wonderful how much energy you have.<br>
<br>
MNCA: Well, thanks.<br>
<br>
CHAN: I mean, especially considering how tough it's been for you to find work.<br>
<br>
MNCA: Well, you know.<br>
<br>
CHAN: You know, I mean, you can't tell your parents you were fired because they'd be
disappointed.<br>
<br>
MNCA: [sad] Uh-huh.<br>
<br>
CHAN: And it's not as if you have a boyfriend's shoulder to cry on.<br>
<br>
MNCA: Well no, but um.<br>
<br>
CHAN: I mean, if it were me, I think I'd have difficulty just getting out of bed at all.<br>
<br>
MNCA: Y'know, I try to stay positive. . .<br>
<br>
CHAN: So, you feel like goin' for a run?<br>
<br>
MNCA: Alright.<br>
<br>
CHAN: Because, you know, you don't have to. If you want, you could just take a nap right
here.<br>
<br>
MNCA: OK. Just for a little while.<br>
<br>
CHAN: OK. [Puts an afghan over her and dances into his room]</font></p>

<p align="center"><strong><font size="3">END</font></strong></p>

<hr>

</html>




208<html>

<head>
<title>The One With the Last</title>
</head>

<body bgcolor="white" text="black" link="green" vlink="black" alink="yellow">

<h1 align="center">The One With the List</h1>

<hr align="center">
<font size="3"><i>

<p>Originally written by Marta Kauffman and David Crane<br>
Trascribed by Mindy Mattingly Phillips <a href="mailto:mmatting@indiana.edu">[mmatting@indiana.edu]</a><br>
Minor additions and adjustments by Dan Silverstein.<br>
</i></font></p>

<hr>
<font size="3">

<p>[Scene: Monica and Rachel's apartment. Phoebe, Monica, and Rachel are there, discussing
the night before.]</p>

<p>RACH: Ross kissed me.</p>

<p>MNCA: Oh my god, oh my god, oh my god!</p>

<p>RACH: It was unbelievable!</p>

<p>MNCA: Oh my god, oh my god, oh my god!</p>

<p>PHOE: Ok, all right. We want to hear everything. Monica, get the wine and unplug the
phone. Rachel, does this end well or do we need to get tissues?</p>

<p>RACH: Oh, it ended very well.</p>

<p>PHOE: Oh.</p>

<p>MNCA: [getting the wine] Do not start without me. Do not start without me.</p>

<p>PHOE: Ok, all right, let's hear about the kiss. Was it like, was it like a soft brush
against your lips? Or was it like a, you know, a &quot;I gotta have you now&quot; kind of
thing?</p>

<p>RACH: Well, at first it was really intense, you know. And then, oh, god, and then we
just sort of sunk into it.</p>

<p>PHOE: Ok, so, ok, was he holding you? Or was his hand like on your back?</p>

<p>RACH: No, actually first they started on my waist. And then, they slid up, and then,
they were in my hair.</p>

<p>PHOE/MNCA: Ohhhh.</p>

<p>[Scene: Ross' apartment. Ross, Chandler, and Joey are there eating pizza.]</p>

<p>ROSS: And, uh, and then I kissed her.</p>

<p>JOEY: Tongue?</p>

<p>ROSS: Yeah.</p>

<p>JOEY: Cool.</p>

<h3 align="center">Opening Credits</h3>

<p>[Scene: <i>Central Perk</i>. Joey, Phoebe, Monica, and Chandler are there; Chandler is
showing everyone his new computer.]</p>

<p>CHAN: All right, check out this bad boy. 12 megabytes of ram. 500 megabyte hard drive.
Built-in spreadsheet capabilities and a modem that transmits at over 28,000 b.p.s.</p>

<p>PHOE: Wow. What are you gonna use it for?</p>

<p>CHAN: [doggedly] Games and stuff.</p>

<p>MNCA: [reading the paper] There are no jobs. There are no jobs for me.</p>

<p>JOEY: [reading over her shoulder] Wait, here's one. Uh, would you be willing to cook
naked?</p>

<p>MNCA: There's an ad for a naked chef?</p>

<p>JOEY: No, but if you're willing to cook naked, then you might be willing to dance
naked. And then... [rubs his fingers together]</p>

<p>[Ross enters, distraught.]</p>

<p>ROSS: Hi.</p>

<p>PHOE: Hey, oh, so, um...how'd you make out last night?</p>

<p>ROSS: That, that is funny. That is painfully funny. No, wait. Wait, yeah, that's just
painful</p>

<p>MNCA: Wait a minute. I thought last night was great.</p>

<p>ROSS: Yeah, it was, but...I get home, ok, and I see Julie's saline solution on my night
table. And I'm thinking to myself, oh my god, what the hell am I doing? I mean, here I am,
I am with Julie, this incredible, great woman, who I care about and who cares about me,
and I'm like, what, am I just gonna throw all that away?</p>

<p>JOEY: You got all that from saline solution?</p>

<p>MNCA: We are talking about Rachel here. You and Rachel.</p>

<p>ROSS: Believe me, I've been dreaming about me and Rachel for ten years now. But now,
I'm with Julie, so it's like me and Julie, me and Rachel, me and Julie, me and... [Rachel
enters, carrying a tray]... Rachel. Rachel, Rachel.</p>

<p>RACH: [to Ross] Hey, you.</p>

<p>ROSS: How are you?</p>

<p>RACH: Good. How are you?</p>

<p>ROSS: Good.</p>

<p>[Julie enters.]</p>

<p>JULIE: Hi, honey.</p>

<p>ROSS: Hi, Julie. [nervous] Hi, Julie. Julie, um, how are you?</p>

<p>JULIE: Good.</p>

<p>ROSS: [uncomfortable] Good, so everybody's here. Everybody's good. So, were you gonna
play something, Phoebe?</p>

<p>PHOE: Oh, well, actually.</p>

<p>ROSS: [impatient] Play it.</p>

<p>PHOE: Ok, all right.</p>

<p>JOEY: Hey, Julie, I didn't know you wore lenses.</p>

<p>JULIE: What?</p>

<p>ROSS: [to Joey] Ssshh.</p>

<p>PHOE: Ok, um, hi, hello, hi, ok, so, um, this is a song about a love triangle between
three people that I made up. Um, it's called, um, &quot;Two of Them Kissed Last
Night&quot;. </p>

<p>[Ross and Rachel look at each other and then at Phoebe, realizing the song is about
their situation.]</p>

<p>PHOE: [singing] There was a girl, we'll call her Betty, and a guy let's call him Neil.
Now I can't stress this point too strongly, this story isn't real. Now our Neil must
decide, who will be the girl that he casts aside. Will Betty be the one who he loves
truly? Or will it be the one who we'll call Ju...Loolie? He must decide, he must decide,
even though I made him up, he must decide!</p>

<p>[Scene: Mr. Ratstatter's (RTST) office. Monica is there about a job.]</p>

<p>RTST: This is a nice resume. Nice, nice, nice. <i>Muy impressivo.</i></p>

<p>MNCA: So, Mr. Rastatter, what exactly does this job entail? The ad wasn't too clear.</p>

<p>RTST: Mockolate.</p>

<p>MNCA: I'm sorry?</p>

<p>RTST: Mockolate. It's a completely synthetic chocolate substitute.</p>

<p>MNCA: Ohh.</p>

<p>[He pulls out a piece of Mockolate.]</p>

<p>RTST: Go ahead. Try a piece. Yeah, we think that Mockolate is even better than
chocolate.</p>

<p>MNCA: All right. Mmm-mmm.</p>

<p>[She tastes it, and obviously hates it.]</p>

<p>RTST: Yeah?</p>

<p>MNCA: [disgusted, trying not to show it] I love how it crumbles. Now see, your
chocolate doesn't do that.</p>

<p>RTST: No, ma'am. Well, anyhoo, we should be getting our F.D.A. approval any day now,
hopefully, in time for Thanksgiving. See, the way we look at it, chocolate already
dominates most of your major food-preparation holidays: Easter, Christmas, what have you.</p>

<p>MNCA: [still chewing] Mmm-mmm.</p>

<p>RTST: But, we're thinking, given the right marketing, we can make Thanksgiving the
Mockolate holiday.</p>

<p>MNCA: Wow.</p>

<p>RTST: Aren't you going to swallow that?</p>

<p>MNCA: Just waiting for it to stop bubbling.</p>

<p>RTST: Yeah, isn't that great?</p>

<p>MNCA: [with false enthusiasm] Mmm.</p>

<p>RTST: Well, anyhoo, um, we are looking for a couple of chefs who can create some
Thanksgiving-themed recipes. You think you might be interested?</p>

<p>MNCA: Abso...[swallows hard]...lutely. See, I love creating new recipes. I love
Thanksgiving. And, well, now, I love Mockolate.</p>

<p>RTST: Really?</p>

<p>MNCA: Especially the after taste, you know, I'll tell ya, that'll last ya till
Christmas.</p>

<p>[Scene: Monica and Rachel's apartment. Monica and Phoebe are there. Monica is
suggesting Mockolate recipes to Phoebe.]</p>

<p>MNCA: How about Mockolate mousse?</p>

<p>PHOE: It's not, it's not very Thanksgiving-y.</p>

<p>MNCA: Ok, how about pilgrim Mockolate mousse?</p>

<p>PHOE: What makes it pilgrim?</p>

<p>MNCA: We'll put buckles on it.</p>

<p>[Rachel enters.]</p>

<p>RACH: Hey.</p>

<p>PHOE: Hey.</p>

<p>MNCA: Hey.</p>

<p>RACH: Did uh, Ross call?</p>

<p>MNCA: No, I'm sorry.</p>

<p>RACH: Why didn't he call? He's gonna stay with Julie, isn't he? He's gonna stay with
her and she's going to be all, &quot;Hi, I'm Julie, Ross picked me, and we're gonna to get
married, have a lot of kids and dig up stuff together.&quot;</p>

<p>PHOE: No offense, but that sounds nothing like her.</p>

<p>[Scene: Chandler and Joey's apartment. Ross is up in arms about the Rachel/Julie
situation.]</p>

<p>ROSS: I don't know what to do. What am I gonna do? I mean, this, this is like a
complete nightmare.</p>

<p>CHAN: Oh, I know. This must be so hard. Oh, no. Two women love me. They're both
gorgeous and sexy. My wallet's too small for my fifties, and my diamond shoes are too
tight.</p>

<p>JOEY: Hey, here's a thought, Ross. [reaches for the computer]</p>

<p>CHAN: Don't touch the computer. Don't ever touch the computer.</p>

<p>JOEY: Ross, listen. I got two words for you. Threesome.</p>

<p>[Ross gives him an insulted look.]</p>

<p>CHAN: Ok, all right, look. Let's get logical about this, ok? We'll make a list. Rachel
and Julie, pros and cons. Oh. We'll put their names in bold, with different fonts, and I
can use different colors for each column.</p>

<p>ROSS: Can't we just use a pen?</p>

<p>CHAN: No, Amish boy.</p>

<p>JOEY: Ok, let's start with the cons, 'cause they're more fun. All right, Rachel first.</p>

<p>ROSS: I don't know. I mean, all right, I guess you can say she's a little spoiled
sometimes.</p>

<p>JOEY: You could say that.</p>

<p>ROSS: And I guess, you know, sometimes, she's a little ditzy, you know. And I've seen
her be a little too into her looks. Oh, and Julie and I, we have a lot in common 'cause
we're both paleontologists, but Rachel's just a waitress.</p>

<p>CHAN: Waitress. Got it. You guys wanna play Doom? Or we could keep doing this. What
else?</p>

<p>ROSS: I don't know.</p>

<p>JOEY: Oh, her ankles are a little chubby.</p>

<p>CHAN: Ok, let's do Julie. What's wrong with her?</p>

<p>ROSS: [long pause] She's not Rachel.</p>

<p>[Scene: Monica and Rachel's apartment. Monica has made food for Phoebe and Rachel to
taste.]</p>

<p>MNCA: Ok, this is pumpkin pie with mockolate cookie crumb crust. This is mockolate
cranberry cake, and these are mockolate chip cookies. Just like the Indians served.</p>

<p>[Rachel takes a bite.]</p>

<p>RACH: Oh my god.</p>

<p>MNCA: Oh my god good?</p>

<p>RACH: Oh my god, I can't believe you let me put this in my mouth.</p>

<p>[Rachel runs to the sink to spit it out.]</p>

<p>PHOE: Oh, oh sweet Lord! This is what evil must taste like!</p>

<p>[Scene: Chandler and Joey's apartment. Chandler is on the phone with a computer
hotline.]</p>

<p>CHAN: I'm telling you this thing won't print. Yes, I pressed that button like 100
times. You know, for a hot line you are not so hot. What? What is that in the background?
Are you watching Star Trek?</p>

<p>[Ross enters with a melancholy look.]</p>

<p>JOEY: [to Ross] Hey, so how'd it go with Julie? Did you, did you break her heart?</p>

<p>ROSS: Yes, it was horrible. She cried. I cried. She threw things, they hit me. Anyway,
I did the right thing.</p>

<p>CHAN: [in phone] So, Spock actually hugs his father?</p>

<p>[Rachel enters.]</p>

<p>RACH: Hey, do you guys have...[sees Ross, pauses]...hi.</p>

<p>ROSS: Hi.</p>

<p>RACH: [sees his coat on] Where you goin'?</p>

<p>ROSS: I uh, I just got back from uh, from Julie's.</p>

<p>RACH: [dejected] Oh.</p>

<p>ROSS: No, no, uh, it's not what you think. It's um the other thing.</p>

<p>RACH: Well, what's the other thing, what do I think?</p>

<p>[Joey is looking at Rachel, smiling, and gesturing his head towards Ross.]</p>

<p>ROSS: Well, uh.</p>

<p>JOEY: He broke up with Julie. Well, go hug her, for god's sakes.</p>

<p>RACH: Really?</p>

<p>ROSS: Really. It's always been you, Rach.</p>

<p>[Ross and Rachel hug.]</p>

<p>RACH: Oh, god.</p>

<p>JOEY/CHAN: Ohhh.</p>

<p>RACH: Oh, oh, this is good, this is really good.</p>

<p>ROSS: I know, I know, it's, it's almost...[turns around, sees Chandler and Joey] What
do you say we go take a walk, just us, not them?</p>

<p>RACH: Let me get my coat.</p>

<p>ROSS: Ok. No, hey, whoa, whoa, I'll get your coat.</p>

<p>[Ross leaves.]</p>

<p>RACH: Ok, he's goin' to get my coat. He's goin' to get my coat. Oh my god, you guys. I
can't believe this. This is unbelievable. [notices Chandler's computer screen] What's
that?</p>

<p>CHAN: [nervous] What? Nothing.</p>

<p>[Chandler closes up the laptop computer screen.]</p>

<p>RACH: What's that? What? I saw my name. What is it?</p>

<p>CHAN: No, no, see? See? [the printer starts to run] Hey, it's printing. [to Joey,
rattled] Hey, it's printing!</p>

<p>[Chandler rips off the sheet of paper from the printer.]</p>

<p>RACH: Well what is it? Let me see.</p>

<p>[Ross walks back in, Rachel's coat in hand.]</p>

<p>ROSS: Hey, someone order a coat?</p>

<p>RACH: Ross, Chandler wrote something about me on his computer and he won't let me see.</p>

<p>ROSS: He won't? [remembers what it is] He won't! Because, isn't that, isn't that the,
the short story you were writing?</p>

<p>CHAN: Yes, yes it is, short story, that I was writing.</p>

<p>RACH: And I'm in it? Then let me read it.</p>

<p>CHAN, JOEY, ROSS: No!</p>

<p>RACH: Come on.</p>

<p>JOEY: Hey, uh, why don't you read it to her?</p>

<p>[Ross and Chandler stare angrily at Joey, who thinks he has come up with a good idea.]</p>

<p>CHAN: [through gritted teeth] Alright. [clears his throat] &quot;It was summer, and it
was hot. Rachel was there. A lonely gray couch. 'Oh, look,' cried Ned, and then the
kingdom was his forever. The end.&quot;</p>

<p>ROSS: That's it? That's all you wrote? You're the worst writer in the whole world.</p>

<p>RACH: All right, you know what? This isn't funny anymore. There's something about me on
that piece of paper and I want to see it.</p>

<p>ROSS: No, you don't.</p>

<p>RACH: All right, you know what, that's fine. If you guys want to be children about
this, that's fine. I do not need to see it. [Rachel grabs the paper and runs across the
room, reading it to herself.]</p>

<p>RACH: What is this? Ross, what is this?</p>

<p>CHAN: Good luck.</p>

<p>[Chandler and Joey leave quickly.]</p>

<p>ROSS: Ok, just, just remember how crazy I am about you, ok?</p>

<p>RACH: Kind of ditzy? Too into her looks? Spoiled?</p>

<p>ROSS: Now that's a little spoiled. He was supposed to type &quot;little&quot;, the
idiot.</p>

<p>RACH: Just a waitress?</p>

<p>ROSS: No, that, that was, I mean, as opposed to uh, the uh, ok. Is this over yet Rach?</p>

<p>RACH: Oh! I do not have chubby ankles!</p>

<p>[Rachel leaves, and Ross follows her into the hall.]</p>

<p>ROSS: No, no, wait, ok, ok, look at the other side. Look at Julie's column.</p>

<p>RACH: She is not <i>Rachem</i>. What the hell's a Rachem? Is that some stupid
paleontology word that I wouldn't know because I'm just a waitress.</p>

<p>[She goes into her apartment and slams the door.]</p>

<p>ROSS: No, Rach, come on. Rach! Rach, no, no! She's not Rachel, she is, she is not,
Ra--Rachel?</p>

<p>[Scene: <i>Central Perk</i>. Chandler, Monica, Joey, and Phoebe are there.]</p>

<p>CHAN: My diary! My diary, that's brilliant. I should have told her it was my diary, she
never would have made me read her my diary.</p>

<p>MNCA: You know, that's true. You'd be a great person to have around the day after an
emergency.</p>

<p>PHOE: I... I cannot believe Ross even made this list. What a dinkus.</p>

<p>JOEY: Hey, cut him some slack. It was Chandler's idea.</p>

<p>PHOE: What?</p>

<p>MNCA: What?</p>

<p>CHAN: Oh good, I was hoping that would come up.</p>

<p>MNCA: This was your idea?</p>

<p>PHOE: What were you thinking?</p>

<p>CHAN: [squirming] All right, let's get some perspective here, ok? These things, they
happen for a reason.</p>

<p>MNCA: Yeah. You!</p>

<p>CHAN: All right, Pheebs, back me up here, ok? You believe in that karma crap, don't
you?</p>

<p>PHOE: Yeah, by the way, good luck in your next life as a dung beetle.</p>

<p>[Scene: Monica and Rachel's apartment. Rachel is sitting on the couch, eating candy. It
is raining out. Ross climbs up the fire escape and is knocking on the window.]</p>

<p>ROSS: Rach! Whoops! Rach, hey, open up, please!</p>

<p>RACH: [coldly] When somebody does not buzz you in, Ross, that means go away. That
doesn't mean please climb up the fire escape.</p>

<p>ROSS: I just wanna read something. It's your pro list.</p>

<p>RACH: Not interested.</p>

<p>[Rachel closes the drapes over the window, goes into her bedroom and closes the door.]</p>

<p>ROSS: [reading his list] Ok, ok, number one: The way you cry at game shows. Number two:
how much you love your friends. Number three: the way you play with your hair when you're
nervous. Number four: how brave you are for starting your life over. Number five: how
great you are with Ben. </p>

<p>[Monica, Chandler, Joey, and Phoebe enter, confused.]</p>

<p>ROSS: Number six: the way you smell.</p>

<p>JOEY: [opens the drapes] Hey, Ross! What are you doin'?</p>

<p>ROSS: Hey, Joey. You wanna open the window?</p>

<p>JOEY: Oh, yeah, I do.</p>

<p>[He opens the window, Ross comes in, soaked.]</p>

<p>CHAN: What are you doing out there?</p>

<p>ROSS: I am, uh, I am...</p>

<p>MNCA: Oh, you must be freezing. You know what you need? How about a nice steaming cup
of hot Mockolate?</p>

<p>[Ross runs to Rachel's bedroom, knocking on the door.]</p>

<p>ROSS: Rach, come on, open up. Rach, come on, come on, Rach. You got to give me another
chance.</p>

<p>[Rachel opens the door.]</p>

<p>RACH: No.</p>

<p>ROSS: No?</p>

<p>RACH: That's what I said.</p>

<p>CHAN: Look, maybe we should go?</p>

<p>RACH: No, you guys, you really don't have to go, we're done talking.</p>

<p>ROSS: Rach, come on, look, I know how you must feel.</p>

<p>RACH: [near tears] No, you don't, Ross. Imagine the worst things you think about
yourself. Now, how would you feel if the one person that you trusted the most in the world
not only thinks them too, but actually uses them as reasons not to be with you.</p>

<p>ROSS: No, but, but I wanna be with you in <b>spite</b> of all those things.</p>

<p>RACH: Oh, well, that's, that's mighty big of you, Ross. [to the others] I said don't
go!</p>

<p>ROSS: You know what? You know what? If, things were the other way around, there's
nothing you could put on a list that would ever make me not want to be with you.</p>

<p>RACH: Well, then, I guess that's the difference between us. See, I'd never make a list.</p>

<p>[She closes the door in his face. Ross walks sullenly back to the couch and sits down.
A moment of silence ensues.]</p>

<p>JOEY: [quietly] I never know how long you're supposed to wait in this type of a
situation before you can talk again, you know? [Ross stares blankly at him] Maybe a little
longer.</p>

<p>[Scene: Mr. Ratstatter's office. Monica is there.]</p>

<p>MNCA: Now, in some of these recipes, the quantities may seem just a little unusual, uh,
like these coconut mockolate holiday nut bars. I've indicated four cups of coconut, and
four cups of crushed nut, and only, uh, one tablespoon of mockolate.</p>

<p>RTST: Doesn't matter.</p>

<p>MNCA: What?</p>

<p>RTST: Our FDA approval didn't come through. Something about laboratory rats.</p>

<p>MNCA: Oh, gosh, I'm sorry.</p>

<p>RTST: Yeah, well, anyhoo, here is your check. [hands it to her] Thank you for all the
trouble you went through. Um, listen, you didn't eat a lot of it while you were cooking,
did you?</p>

<p>MNCA: Well, uh, I ate some.</p>

<p>RTST: Oh, some, that's fine. Some is fine. Some is not a lot. So, it doesn't burn when
you pee, does it?</p>

<p>[Scene: Monica and Rachel's apartment. Monica and Rachel are there.]</p>

<p>(phone rings)</p>

<p>MNCA: Hello?</p>

<p>[Ross is at his apartment.]</p>

<p>ROSS: Hi.</p>

<p>RACH: [to Monica] Is that him again? Tell him I'd come to the phone, but my ankles are
weighin' me down.</p>

<p>MNCA: [to Ross] Listen, I... I don't think this is the best time.</p>

<p>ROSS: Look, can, can you do something for me?</p>

<p>MNCA: Sure, what? Ok, ok. [hangs up the phone] [to Rachel] Music?</p>

<p>[Monica turns on the radio.]</p>

<p>RADIO: The next one's dedicated to Rachel from Ross. Rachel, he wants you to know he's
deeply sorry for what he did and he hopes you can find it in your heart to forgive him. (<i>With
or Without You </i>plays) </p>

<p>[Rachel seems touched. She pauses for a moment, then picks up the phone and starts to
dial. Cut to Ross at his apartment.]</p>

<p>RADIO: Uh, we've just gotten a call from Rachel, and she told us what Ross did. It's
pretty appalling, and Ross, if you're listening, I don't wanna play your song anymore. Why
don't we devote our time to a couple that stands a chance? Avery, Michelle's sorry she hit
you with her car and she hopes you two will work it out.</p>

<p>[Scene: Mr. Ratstatter's office. Monica is there.]</p>

<p>RTST: Hi, thanks for coming in again.</p>

<p>MNCA: Oh, not at all. I have no morals and I need the cash.</p>

<p>RTST: It's like I'm lookin' in a mirror. Anyway, they're called
&quot;fishtachios&quot;. They taste exactly like pistachios, but they're made primarily of
reconstituted fish bits. Here, try one. You're not allergic to anything, are you?</p>

<p>MNCA: Cat hair.</p>

<p>RTST: Oh, sorry.</p>
<font size="4"><b>

<p align="center">END</b></font> </font></p>

<hr>

209<html>

<head>
<title>The One With Phoebe's Dad</title>
</head>

<body bgcolor="white" text="black" link="green" vlink="black" alink="yellow">

<h1 align="center">The One With Phoebe's Dad</h1>

<hr align="center">
<font size="3"><i>

<p>Originally written by Jeffrey Astroff and Mike Sikowitz<br>
Transcribed by Josh Hodge.<br>
Minor additions and adjustments by Dan SIlverstein.</i></font><br>
</p>

<hr>
<font size="3">

<p align="left">[Scene: Monica and Rachel's apartment. Monica, Rachel, Ross, and Phoebe
are there. Phoebe is looking out the window.]<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh, ooh. Ugly Naked Guy is decorating his tree. Oh my God, you
should see the size of his Christmas Balls.<br>
<br>
[Chandler and Joey enter.]<br>
<br>
JOEY: Hey.<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: Hey.<br>
<br>
RACHEL: Hey.<br>
<br>
JOEY: Hey, how much did you guys tip the super this year?<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: Yeah, we were gonna give fifty, but if you guys gave more, we don't wanna look
bad.<br>
<br>
MONICA: Oh, actually this year we just made him homemade cookies.<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: And twenty-five it is.<br>
<br>
JOEY: You gave him cookies?<br>
<br>
MONICA: Money is so impersonal. Cookies says someone really cares. . . Alright, we're
broke, but cookies do say that.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: I can see that. A plate of brownies once told me a limerick.<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: Phoebs, let me ask you something, were, were these, uh, funny brownies?<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Not especially. But you know what, I think they had pot in them.<br>
<br>
ROSS: So you guys, who else did you tip with cookies?<br>
<br>
RACHEL: Uhh, the mailman, the super.<br>
<br>
[There's a bang at the door.]<br>
<br>
MONICA: Oh, and the newspaper delivery guy.<br>
<br>
[Joey opens the door and picks up the remnants of the newspaper.<br>
<br>
JOEY: Oh my God.<br>
<br>
RACHEL: What?<br>
<br>
JOEY: Uhhh, I don't think you're gonna like this.<br>
<br>
[Joey shows them the torn-up newspaper.]<br>
<br>
RACHEL: Ooh, goooosh, ooh, these are cookies smashed in the sports section.<br>
<br>
MONICA: Oh look, and he did my crossword puzzle.<br>
<br>
ROSS: Yeah, but not very well, unless 14-across, 'Gershwin musical' actually is
bitemebitemebitemebiteme.<br>
<br>
<font size="4">OPENING TITLES</font><br>
<br>
[Scene: <i>Central Perk</i>. Monica, Chandler, and Joey are seated at couches. Rachel is
working behind the counter.]<br>
<br>
JOEY: I can't believe it's Christmas already. Ya know, I mean, one day your eatin' turkey,
the next thing ya know, your lords are a-leapin' and you geese are a-layin'.<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: Which is why geese are so relaxed this time of year.<br>
<br>
[Ross enters with several bags from shopping.]<br>
<br>
ROSS: Hey guys.<br>
<br>
CHANDLER, MONICA, and JOEY: Hey.<br>
<br>
[Ross approaches Rachel at counter.]<br>
<br>
ROSS: Hey Rach. I, uh, got you a little present. [Rachel is not impressed]. . I'll open
it. It's a Slinky! Remember, huh. [sings] <i>Walks down stairs, alone or in pairs,
everyone knows it's</i>. . . just a big spring. Alright, you still mad at me becuase of
the whole. . .<br>
<br>
RACHEL: Horrible and degrading list of reasons not to be with me?<br>
<br>
ROSS: How 'bout from now on we just call it the 'unfortunate incident'? [Rachel walks off]
Hey Gunther, you got stairs in your place?<br>
<br>
GUNTHER: Yeah.<br>
<br>
ROSS: Here, go nuts. [gives him the Slinky and goes and sits with others at the couches]<br>
<br>
ROSS: Hey guys.<br>
<br>
CHANDLER, MONICA, and JOEY: Hey.<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: What's in the bag?<br>
<br>
ROSS: Um, just some presents.<br>
<br>
JOEY: C'mon show us what you bought. . . You know you want to.<br>
<br>
ROSS: [childishly] OK. OK, this is a picture frame from Ben to my parents, huh.<br>
<br>
MONICA: Cute.<br>
<br>
ROSS: I got some, uh, hers and hers towels for Susan and Carol. And, uh, I got this blouse
for mom.<br>
<br>
[Ross holds up the blouse. It is extremely tacky, with sewn-on medals hanging off of it.]<br>
<br>
MONICA: Ross, that is gorgeous!<br>
<br>
ROSS: Yeah?<br>
<br>
MONICA: Look at these authentic fake medals. I tell ya, mom's gonna be voted best dressed
at the make-believe military academy.<br>
<br>
[Phoebe enters.]<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Hey.<br>
<br>
GANG: Hey. Hi Phoebe.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Happy Christmas Eve Eve. [sees Ross's picture frame] Oh my God, where did you get
this?<br>
<br>
ROSS: Uh, Macy's, third floor, home furnishings.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: This is my father, this is a picture of my dad.<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: Nah, Phoebs, that's the guy that comes in the frame.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: No it isn't, this is my dad, alright, I'll show you.<br>
<br>
RACHEL: Phoebe, I thought your dad was in prison.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: No, that's my stepdad. My real dad's the one that ran out on us before I was born.<br>
<br>
RACHEL: How have you never been on Oprah?<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: [showing her pictures] OK, look, see, this is him. My mother gave me this picture
before she died, same guy.<br>
<br>
MONICA: Honey, uh, this is a picture of the frame guy posing in front of a bright blue
screen with a collie.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: It's not a blue screen... it's just, maybe it was just really clear that day. OK,
I have to talk to my grandmother. [turns to leave]<br>
<br>
MONICA: Oh, wait a minute honey.<br>
<br>
GANG: Phoebs. [Phoebe leaves]<br>
<br>
MONICA: Wow.<br>
<br>
JOEY: So anyway, I'm trying to get my boss's ex-wife to sleep with me. . .<br>
<br>
GANG: Joey!<br>
<br>
JOEY: Oh, but when Phoebe has a problem, everyone's all ears!<br>
<br>
[Scene: Phoebe's grandmother's place. Phoebe's grandmother is sitting at the table,
reading the obituaries, and crossing out names in the phonebook.]<br>
<br>
GRANDMOTHER: Esther Livingston. [scratches out name] Gone.<br>
<br>
[Phoebe enters.]<br>
<br>
GRANDMOTHER: Hi, Phoe.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Hi Gram. Whatcha doin'?<br>
<br>
GRANDMOTHER: Oh, just updating the phonebook.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Um, gram, um, can I see the pictures of my dad again?<br>
<br>
GRANDMOTHER: [nervously] Oh. Oh, sure, sure, uh, uh, how come?<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Just, you know, to see... um.<br>
<br>
GRANDMOTHER: Oh, sure, yeah. [gets a box with the pictures] This is the one of you father
in a meadow, and, uh, helping a little boy fly a kite, and here he is at a graduation. . .
another graduation. . . another graduation.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: OK, is this really my father?<br>
<br>
GRANDMOTHER: Is it really your fa--I can't... well of course it is.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: OK, I smell smoke. Maybe that's 'cause someone's pants are on fire.<br>
<br>
GRANDMOTHER: Look, I. . .<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Ya know, in all the years that we have been grandmother and granddaughter, you
have never lied to me.<br>
<br>
GRANDMOTHER: Alright, that is not your father, that's just a picture of a guy in a frame.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Oh God.<br>
<br>
GRANDMOTHER: It was your mother's idea. Ya know, she didn't want you to know your real
father because it hurt her so much when he left, and, I didn't want to go along with it,
but, well then she died and, and it was harder to argue with her. Not impossible, but
harder.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Alright, so, what, he's not a famous tree surgeon? And then, I guess, OK, he
doesn't live in a hut in Burma where there's no phones?<br>
<br>
GRANDMOTHER: Last I heard, he was a pharmacist somewhere upstate.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: OK, that makes no sense. Why would the villagers worship a pharmacist?<br>
<br>
GRANDMOTHER: Honey.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: [realizes] Oh.<br>
<br>
GRANDMOTHER: Anyway, that's all I know. That, and this. [pulls apart a frame and pulls a
picture out] This is the real him.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Oh.<br>
<br>
[Scene: Monica and Rachel's apartment. Rachel, Chandler, and Joey are decorating the
Christmas tree.]<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: Ya know I remember my father, all dressed up in the red suit, the big black
boots, and the patent leather belt, sneakin around downstairs. He didn't want anybody to
see him but he'd be drunk so he'd stumble, crash into something and wake everybody up.<br>
<br>
RACHEL: Well, that doesn't sound like a very merry Christmas.<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: Who said anything about Christmas?<br>
<br>
[Monica and Ross enter.]<br>
<br>
MONICA: Hi.<br>
<br>
ROSS: Hey, anyone hear from Phoebe yet?<br>
<br>
RACHEL: No, nothin'.<br>
<br>
MONICA: I hope she's OK.<br>
<br>
JOEY: Yeah, I know exactly what she's goin' through.<br>
<br>
MONICA: How do you know exactly what she's going through?<br>
<br>
JOEY: She told us.<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: So whaddya got there Monica?<br>
<br>
MONICA: Just some stuff for the party.<br>
<br>
ROSS: Yeah, what're you guys doin' here, aren't you supposed to be Christmas shopping?<br>
<br>
MONICA: You guys haven't gotten your presents yet? Tomorrow's Christmas Eve, what're ya
gonna do?<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: Don't you have to be Claymation to say stuff like that?<br>
<br>
RACHEL: Oh, by the way Mon, I don't think the mailman liked your cookies. Here are the
ornaments your mom sent. [hands her a smashed box]<br>
<br>
MONICA: Well, maybe the mailman liked the cookies, we just didn't give him enough.<br>
<br>
JOEY: Monica, pigeons learn faster that you.<br>
<br>
[Ross approaches Rachel, away from everyone else.]</p>

<p>ROSS: Hey, Rach, you know what? I think, I think I know what'll make you feel better.
How 'bout you make a list about me.<br>
<br>
RACHEL: Wha... forget it Ross, no, I am not gonna stand here and make a list of. . .<br>
<br>
ROSS: C'mon Rachel.<br>
<br>
RACHEL: OK, you're whiney, you are, you're obsessive, you are insecure, you're, you're
gutless, you know, you don't ever, you don't just sort of seize the day, you know. You
like me for what, a year, you didn't do anything about it. And, uh, oh, you wear too much
of that gel in your hair.<br>
<br>
ROSS: See there, you uhh, alright, ya, you did what I said.<br>
<br>
RACHEL: Yeah, and you know what? You're right, I do feel better, thank you Ross. [she
walks off and Ross puts his hand to his hair]<br>
<br>
[Scene: Back at Phoebe's. She is on the phone]<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Yeah, um, in Albany, can I have the number of Frank Buffay. . . OK, um, in Ithica.
. . alright, um, Saratoga. . . Oneonta. Alright, you know what, you shouldn't call youself
information. [hangs up]<br>
<br>
[Phoebe's grandmother enters]<br>
<br>
GRANDMOTHER: Hey.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Hello grandma, if that is in fact your real name.<br>
<br>
GRANDMOTHER: C'mon now Phoe, don't still be mad at me. How's it going?<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Well, not so good. Upstate's pretty big, he's pretty small, you do the math.<br>
<br>
GRANDMOTHER: Well, I think you're better off without him. Oh honey, I know he's your daddy
but, but to me he's still the irresponsible creep who knocked up your mom and stole her
Gremlin.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: No I just, just wanted to know who he was, ya know.<br>
<br>
GRANDMOTHER: I know. OK, I wasn't completely honest with you when I told you that, uh, I
didn't know exactly where he lived.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Whattaya mean?<br>
<br>
GRANDMOTHER: He lives at 74 Laurel Drive in Middletown. If you hit the Dairy Queen, you've
gone too far. You can take my cab.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Wow. Thank you.<br>
<br>
GRANDMOTHER: Now, remember, nobody else drives that cab.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Uh-huh, got it. Ooh, I'm gonna see my dad. Wish me luck, Grandpa! [blows a kiss to
a picture of Einstein]<br>
<br>
</p>

<h3 align="center">Commercial</h3>

<p>[Scene: Chandler is standing on a street corner waiting for Phoebe in the cab. Joey
walks up.]<br>
<br>
JOEY: Phoebe here with the cab yet?<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: Yeah, she, she brought the invisible cab. . . hop in.<br>
<br>
JOEY: Well she better get here soon, the outlet stores close at 7.<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: Hey, don't worry. I figure it'll be 2 hours to Phoebe's dad's house, they'll
meet, they'll chat, they'll swap life stories, we'll still have plenty of time.<br>
<br>
[Phoebe drives up in the cab]<br>
<br>
JOEY: Hey, here she comes.<br>
<br>
Chandler: Hey.<br>
<br>
JOEY: Hey.<br>
<br>
[Phoebe runs over the curb. Joey gets in the back seat, Chandler in the front]<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Hey.<br>
<br>
JOEY: Hey.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Can you believe this. In, like, two hours I'm gonna have a dad. Eeeshk.<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: Eeeshk.<br>
<br>
JOEY: Yeah, big stuff.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: OK, let's go.<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: OK.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Alright, here, you have to hold this. [hands Chandler a piece of paper]<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: OK. [reads paper] Brake left, gas right?<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Uh-huh, yeah, that's my cheat sheet.<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: [grabs for seat belt] Where's my seat belt?<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Oh, no no, that side doesn't have one, the paramedics had to cut through it.
[Chandler jumps out of the car]<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: [Chandler gets in the back seat] Hey!<br>
<br>
JOEY: Hey. [Phoebe takes off, Joey and Chandler are thrown back in the seat]<br>
<br>
[Scene: Monica and Rachel's apartment. Monica is preparing for the party with Ross
questioning her.]<br>
<br>
ROSS: C'mon, just tell me, please, please.<br>
<br>
MONICA: For the sixteenth time, no... I do not think you're obsessive.<br>
<br>
[Rachel enters from her room]<br>
<br>
RACHEL: Oh, gosh, it's hot in here.<br>
<br>
MONICA: Rach, get the heat. [Rachel holds up her hand with wet fingernail polish] Ross,
could you turn the heat down please?<br>
<br>
ROSS: Sure. By the way, there's a difference between being obsessive and. . .<br>
<br>
MONICA: Ross, the heat!<br>
<br>
ROSS: Fine, OK! Heat, heat, heat, and I'm the obsessive one. [goes to the radiator and
starts turning the knob] OK, this way is on, so this is. . . [breaks off the knob] off.<br>
<br>
RACHEL: Did you just break the radiator?<br>
<br>
ROSS: No, no, I was turnin' the knob and, and. . . here it is.<br>
<br>
MONICA: Well put it back.<br>
<br>
ROSS: It uhh, it won't go back.<br>
<br>
RACHEL: I'll call the super.<br>
<br>
MONICA: Here, let me try.<br>
<br>
ROSS: Oh, oh that's right, I forgot about your ability to fuse metal.<br>
<br>
MONICA: Hey, it's Funny's cousin, Not Funny.<br>
<br>
RACHEL: [on phone] Hi, Mr. Treeger. Hi, it's Rachel Green from upstairs. Yes, <i>somebody</i>,
uh, broke our knob on the radiator and it's really hot in here. Yes, it's, it's hot enough
to bake cookies. Well, do you think we could have a new one by 6? Wha t, no, no, Tuesday,
we can't wait until Tuesday, we're having a party tonight.<br>
<br>
ROSS: OK, tip the man.<br>
<br>
MONICA: No, if he doesn't like our cookies, too bad, I am not gonna be blackmailed. Look
if worse comes to worse, it gets a little warm, we'll call it a theme party.<br>
<br>
ROSS: Hey, here's a theme: Come on in, live like bacon.<br>
<br>
[Scene: Outside Phoebe's dad's house. The cab pulls up.]<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Ooh, this is it, 74. [screeches to a halt, Joey and Chandler are thrown into the
plexiglass wall in the cab]<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: Oh, so that's what this is for.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Wow, this is it, I'm gonna meet my dad. This is like the biggest thing ever, huh.<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: Yeah.<br>
<br>
JOEY: Sure is.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: OK, here I go. I'm goin' in.<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: Alright.<br>
<br>
JOEY: Good luck Phoebs.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: OK, here I go. . . here I go. . . I'm goin'. [she just sits in the cab]<br>
<br>
[Scene: Monica and Rachel's apartment. They are having their party. All the guests are
stripped down because of the heat.]<br>
<br>
RACHEL: [answers door] Hi, welcome to our tropical Christmas party. You can put your coats
and sweaters and pants and shirts in the bedroom.<br>
<br>
ROSS: [sitting at table talking to a girl] It's hard to tell because I'm sweating, but I
use exactly what the gel bottle says, an amount about the size of a pea. How, how can that
be too much?<br>
<br>
MONICA: [carrying an ice cube tray] Ice, ice, ice squares anyone? Take a napkin. Alright.<br>
<br>
ROSS: Monica, Monica, your guest are turning into jerky, OK.<br>
<br>
MONICA: Really? I'm perfectly comfortable. [one of the guest opens the refrigerator] Hey,
hey, hey, get in line buddy, I was next. [she opens the refrigerator and leans into it]<br>
<br>
RACHEL: [answering the door] Mr. Treeger.<br>
<br>
MR. TREEGER: Uhh, you said there was a party.<br>
<br>
RACHEL: Oh, yeah, well hey, welcome to our sauna.<br>
<br>
MR. TREEGER: Ahh, is it hot? My body always stays cool, probably 'cause I have so much
skin. Hey, cheese!<br>
<br>
[Ross is speaking to Monica and Rachel about tipping the super.]</p>

<p>ROSS: Alright, alright, here's the chance. Monica give him cash, Rachel give him your
earrings. Something, now, anything.<br>
<br>
MONICA: No, I will not cave.<br>
<br>
RACHEL: Yeah, I'm with Mon.<br>
<br>
ROSS: Alright, alright, you know how you say I never seize the day? Well, alright, even
though he's your super, I'm seizing. [approaches Mr. Treeger] Mr. Treeger, here is 50
bucks, merry Christmas.<br>
<br>
[Gives him the cash.]</p>

<p align="left">MR. TREEGER: Oh wow, I didn't get you anything. Here's five back.<br>
<br>
ROSS: No no, no, that, that's your Christmas tip, alright. Oh, hey, do you think there's a
chance you could fix that radiator now?<br>
<br>
MR. TREEGER: No can do, like I told the girl, I can't get a new knob until Thursday.<br>
<br>
MONICA: Ross.<br>
<br>
ROSS: Yeah.<br>
<br>
MONICA: [to Ross] Looks like he's playin' baseball.<br>
<br>
ROSS: You mean hardball?<br>
<br>
MONICA: Whatever.<br>
<br>
RACHEL: What'cha gonna' do?<br>
<br>
ROSS: Excuse me, I'm seizing. Mr. Treeger, here's another 50, happy Hanukkah. Will uh,
will this help with the knob getting?<br>
<br>
MR. TREEGER: No, the place is not open 'till Tuesday. Am I not saying it right.<br>
<br>
MONICA: So, wait, you really did like my cookies?<br>
<br>
MR. TREEGER: Oh, yeah, they were so personal, really showed you cared.<br>
<br>
RACHEL: Nice seizing. . . gel boy.<br>
<br>
MR. TREEGER: [to Rachel who is standing under mistletoe] So, uh, is this, uh, mistletoe?<br>
<br>
RACHEL: Huh-huh, no act--no, uhh, that, that is basil.<br>
<br>
MR. TREEGER: Ahh, if it was mistletoe, I was gonna kiss ya.<br>
<br>
RACHEL: Huh-hoo, yeah, no, it's still basil.<br>
<br>
[Scene: Outside Phoebe's dad's house. Phoebe is running back to the cab.]<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: OK.<br>
<br>
JOEY: How far'd ya get?<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Mailbox.<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: Alright, we're gettin' closer.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Uh-huh.<br>
<br>
JOEY: Phoebs, what's goin' on?<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: No, it's just like, ya know, it's a whole mess of stuff, ya know. It's like,
yesterday, ya know, my dad was this, like, famous Burma tree surgeon guy and, ya know, now
he's a, a pharmacist guy and. . .<br>
<br>
JOEY: Well, maybe he's, maybe he's this really cool pharmacist guy.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Yeah, maybe, yeah. You know, and, and I'll knock on the door and, and he'll hug me
and I'll have a dad. Ya know and I'll, I'll go to his pharmacy and everyone will be really
nice to me 'cause, you know, I'm Franks daughter.<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: Well, so why not go knock?<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Well, 'cause, I mean, what if, what if he's not this great dad guy? I mean, what
if, what if he's just still the dirtbag who ran out on my mom and us? You know what? I've
already lost a fake dad this week and I don't think I'm ready to lose a real one.<br>
<br>
JOEY: Phoebs, that's OK. You took a big step today.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Yeah?<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: Yeah, and someday when you're ready, you'll make it past the hedges.<br>
<br>
JOEY: Yeah, and when you do, he'll be lucky to have you.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: You guys. I'm sorry about your shopping.<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: Oh, that's OK, we'll figure something out.<br>
<br>
JOEY: Uh, listen Phoebs, I know you're not goin' in there but do you think it'd be alright
if I went in and used his bathroom? Oh, that's fine, never mind. Cool, snow, kinda like a
blank canvas.<br>
<br>
[Scene: Monica and Rachel's apartment. Ross, Monica, and Rachel are sitting around after
the party. Chandler, Joey, and Phoebe enter.]<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: Ho, ho, ho, holy crap is it hot in here!<br>
<br>
JOEY: Really, hey, you mind if I turn the heat down?<br>
<br>
MONICA: Hey, we could have used that kind of thinkin' earlier.<br>
<br>
ROSS: Hey, Phoebs, how'd it go.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Oh, I couldn't go in.<br>
<br>
MONICA: Honey, I'm sorry.<br>
<br>
ROSS: Are you OK?<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Yeah, yeah, no it's OK 'cause, I mean, I know he's there, so, that's enough for
now.<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: Hey, guys, it's after midnight, merry Christmas everyone. [Ross and Phoebe hug,
Monica and Rachel hug, Chandler is left standing]<br>
<br>
JOEY: Hey, Monica, the knob was broken so I just turned it off from underneath, I hope
that's alright.<br>
<br>
<font size="4">CLOSING TITLES</font><br>
<br>
[Scene: Monica and Rachel's apartment. Joey and Chandler are giving out their Christmas
presents out of a cardboard box from a case of motor oil.]<br>
<br>
JOEY: Rach, these are for you.<br>
<br>
RACHEL: Wiper blades. I don't even have a car.<br>
<br>
JOEY: No, but with this new car smell, you'll think you do.<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: OK, Phoebs, your turn.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: Ahh, toilet seat covers! Is that what you were doing while I was getting gas?<br>
<br>
JOEY: Uh-huh.<br>
<br>
PHOEBE: You guuuyys.<br>
<br>
JOEY: And for Ross, Mr. Sweet-tooth.<br>
<br>
ROSS: You got me a cola drink?<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: And, a lemon lime.<br>
<br>
ROSS: Well this, this is too much, I feel like I should get you another sweater.<br>
<br>
CHANDLER: And last but not least.<br>
<br>
[Chandler and Joey give Monica a pack of condoms.]</p>

<p align="left">JOEY: They're ribbed for your pleasure.<br>
<br>
[Ross and Monica trade their gifts.]</font></p>

<p align="center"><strong><font size="3">END</font></strong></p>

<hr>
